page.title: The British Environment and Media Awards

revision.comment: /* top */clean up; http→https for [[The Guardian]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''British Environment and Media Awards''', or BEMAs, were created by [[Media Natura]], and are awarded by the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]]. The awards are open to any professional article, programme, website or campaign, written, produced or undertaken in the UK. Past hosts have included [[Angus Deayton]],<ref name=BEMAs2007>{{cite web|url=http://www.bemas.org.uk/|title=2007 BEMAs|accessdate=2008-01-04}}</ref> and [[Michael Fish]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwf.org.uk/bemas/2004/index.asp|title=2004 BEMAs|accessdate=2008-01-04}}</ref>
In 2007, the year the awards became [[carbon neutral]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwf.org.uk/bemas/2006/index.asp|title=The first Carbon Neutral BEMAs in 2007|publisher=WWF|date=}}</ref> winners included:<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2007/nov/08/pressandpublishing?gusrc=rss&feed=media|title=Guardian wins media award|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|date=2007-08-11 | location=London | first=John | last=Plunkett | accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref> *[[The Guardian Newspaper]] *The [[Financial Times]]'s Fiona Harvey for exposing corruption in the [[carbon offset]] market *The [[BBC]] [[BBC News at Ten|News at Ten]] for its coverage of [[climate change]] *The student organisation [[People & Planet]] for its university environmental performance table, the ''[[The People & Planet Green League|Green League]]''
Some of the award's sponsors, which include the [[RSPB]], have attracted some condemnation, such as [[Surfers Against Sewage]] protest at the 2007 awards where they handed [[Northumbrian Water]] a gold toilet-brush for "showing a disregard to the health of the marine environment".<ref name=Guardian/> Northumbrian Water however insist they are "the leading environmental company in the North East", having "invested some £2 billion on environmental and service improvements since 1990".<ref name=BEMAs2007/>
==See also== *[[Environmental journalism]]
==References== {{reflist}} (dead links)
{{DEFAULTSORT:British Environment and Media Awards}} [[Category:British film awards]] [[Category:British television awards]] [[Category:Environmental awards]]
{{Award-stub}}

{{distinguish|text=the 1941 comedy film ''[[The Devil and Miss Jones]]'', of which it is a [[mockbuster]]}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = The Devil in Miss Jones | image = Devilinmissjonesposter.jpg | caption = The theatrical release poster. | image_size = 225px | director = [[Gerard Damiano]] | producer = Gerard Damiano
[[Harry Reems]] | writer = Gerard Damiano | starring = [[Georgina Spelvin]] | music = Alden Shuman | cinematography = Harry Flecks | editing = Gerard Damiano | distributor = VCX Ltd.
MB Productions | released = {{Film date|1973|03|28}} | runtime = 62 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $15,000,000
{{small|(US theatrical [[gross rental]])}} }} '''''The Devil in Miss Jones''''' is a 1973 [[pornographic film]], written, directed and produced by [[Gerard Damiano]] and starring [[Georgina Spelvin]] and [[Harry Reems]].Lewis, p. 210 It is widely regarded as a classic adult film,{{cite book |title=Porn studies |publisher=Duke University Press |authorlink=[[Linda Williams (film scholar)|author=Williams, Linda]] |year=2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdWZ8JD5dkkC |isbn=0-8223-3312-0 |page=173}} released during the [[Golden Age of Porn]] (1969–1984).{{cite book|title=The hypersexuality of race: performing Asian/American women on screen and scene|publisher=Duke University Press|author=Shimizu, Celine Parreñas |year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BToxwPEf814C|isbn=0-8223-4033-X|page=147}} After his 1972 success with ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'', Damiano shot the film in a house on Park Drive South in the town of Harrison, New York.http://www.artandpopularculture.com/The_Devil_in_Miss_Jones Along with ''Deep Throat'' and ''[[Behind the Green Door]]'', the film is associated with a time in American culture known as "[[Golden Age of Porn#"Porno chic"|porno chic]]",{{cite news |last=Blumenthal |first=Ralph |title=Porno chic; 'Hard-core' grows fashionable-and very profitable |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/01/21/archives/pornochic-hardcore-grows-fashionableand-very-profitable.html |date=January 21, 1973 |work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |accessdate=January 20, 2016 }}[http://www.jahsonic.com/PornoChic.html Porno Chic (Jahsonic.com)] in which [[Pornography|adult erotic]] films were just beginning to be widely released, publicly discussed by celebrities (like [[Johnny Carson]] and [[Bob Hope]]){{cite web |last=Corliss |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Corliss |title=That Old Feeling: When Porno Was Chic |url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1043267,00.html |date=March 29, 2005 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=January 27, 2016 }} and taken seriously by film critics (like [[Roger Ebert]]).{{cite web |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=Alice in Wonderland:An X-Rated Musical Fantasy |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/alice-in-wonderland-1976 |date=November 24, 1976 |work=[[RogerEbert.com]] |accessdate=February 26, 2016 }} ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' went on to spawn numerous remakes and sequels. As with many films of the Golden Age of Porn, the copyright status of ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' is unresolved. VCX claims a copyright; rival distributor Arrow Productions distributed unauthorized copies of the film for a time before 2009, when (as part of a mutual truce between the companies) Arrow agreed to accept VCX's copyright claim in exchange for not challenging Arrow's copyright claim on ''Deep Throat''.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/how-a-nasty-legal-fight-252525 |title=How a Nasty Legal Fight Over 'Deep Throat,' 'Debbie Does Dallas' Was Settled|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=16 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/business-notebook/2009/may/01/porn-nostalgia-industry-heats-las-vegas/|last=Green|first=Steve|title=‘Porn nostalgia’ industry heats up in Las Vegas|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 1, 2009|accessdate=21 January 2017}} ==Plot== [[Georgina Spelvin]] plays Justine Jones, a lonely, [[major depressive disorder|depressed]] [[spinster]] who decides that [[suicide]] is the only way out of her routinely dull existence.[http://www.vcx.com/store/detail.aspx?id=62 1973 Original Edition DVD] product page at [[VCX]] While lying in the bathtub, Justine slits her wrists with a shaving blade and dies quietly as the water fills with her blood.Spelvin, p. 228 Because she has lived a "pure" life, Miss Jones finds herself in [[Limbo]]. There she meets Mr. Abaca (John Clemens), an [[angel]], of sorts, who informs her that she does not qualify for entrance to [[Heaven]] because she has killed herself. Angry that this one indiscretion has left her with only the options of Limbo or [[Hell]], she begs Mr. Abaca to let her "earn" her place in Hell by being allowed to return to Earth and become the embodiment of [[Lust]]. After an intense session of pain and pleasure with a menacing man who goes only by the title of "The Teacher" ([[Harry Reems]]),Spelvin, p. 94 Justine has a few bizarre and sexually deviant encounters, the last of which is a graphic [[group sex|threesome]]. However, just as she is enjoying her new life of lust, the brief time Justine was given to fulfill herself runs out and she is faced with the eternity of Hell. At first, Miss Jones is horrified at the pain she will be forced to endure, but Abaca is quick to dispel the common human myth of Hell and promises Justine that she will be "quite comfortable..." Justine, now a raging [[sex addict]], then finds herself confined to a small room with an [[impotence|impotent]] man who is more interested in catching [[fly|flies]] than her.{{cite book |title=Historical dictionary of the 1970s |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |author=Olson, James Stuart |year=1999 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YKkF8vQRcp0C |isbn=0-313-30543-9 |page=125}} She desperately begs the man for sex, but he simply asks her to be quiet while he listens to the buzzing of his imaginary insects. Trapped in her own private Hell, Miss Jones is left screaming in agony for all eternity, thirsting for a [[Orgasm|climax]] she will never achieve by her own means. ==Cast== * [[Georgina Spelvin]] as Justine Jones * John Clemens as Abaca * [[Harry Reems]] as The Teacher (as Harry Reams) * [[Marc Stevens (actor)|Marc Stevens]] as Second Guy with Justine (as Mark Stevens) * Levi Richards as Third Guy with Justine (as Rick Livermore) * [[Judith Hamilton]] as First Girl with Justine (as Clair Lumiere) * Sue Flaken as Second Girl with Justine * [[Gerard Damiano]] as Man in Cell (as Albert Gork) ==Georgina Spelvin== Spelvin was 36 when she made the film. ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' was one of her first acting appearances following a career as a chorus girl on Broadway where she was featured in productions such as ''Cabaret'', ''Guys and Dolls'', ''Sweet Charity'', and ''The Pajama Game''.[http://www.therialtoreport.com/2013/05/19/podcast-011-georgina-spelvin-the-devil-miss-jones-and-the-new-york-years/ Georgina Spelvin: The Devil, Miss Jones, and the New York Years], The Rialto Report, May 19, 2013 Her role in ''The Devil In Miss Jones'' was typical of her career, as she often played celibate spinsters who have a sexual awakening, then become sex fiends (e.g. ''Sleepyhead''). She also meets a tragic end in several of her other films. The film marked the first time she used the moniker Georgina Spelvin, a reference to [[George Spelvin]], a traditional stagename used to hide a performer's identity, for any number of reasons.Spelvin, p. 7 According to her interview on [[Dave's Old Porn]], Spelvin also did the craft services and cooking on the set. The actress billed in the movie as Claire Lumiere was hired to do craft services only, but was offered $100 to do a lesbian scene with Spelvin, which she accepted. In an audio interview with [[The Rialto Report]] in 2013, Spelvin spoke about how she and Lumiere were lovers at the time and they accepted the adult film work as a means of raising money for their film collective. ==Box office== The movie was given an [[X rating]] by the [[MPAA]]{{cite book|title=The history of sex in American film|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|author=Pennington, Jody W. |year=2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OfAKgZ68a9AC|isbn=0-275-99226-8|page=56}} and premiered at the 57th Street Playhouse in New York City. In many theaters it was shown after ''Deep Throat'' as part of a double bill. ''The Devil In Miss Jones'' broke the box office record for a pornographic film.Lewis, p. 218 It was more commercially successful than both ''Deep Throat'' and ''Behind the Green Door'', and successfully competed against mainstream films.Lewis, p. 112 It earned $15 million in [[gross rental]] at the U.S. box office, making it the tenth most successful film of 1973, just behind ''[[Paper Moon (film)|Paper Moon]]'' with [[Ryan O'Neal]] and ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' with Roger Moore.{{cite book |first=Peter |last=Krämer |year=2005 |title=The new Hollywood: from Bonnie and Clyde to Star Wars |publisher=Wallflower Press |isbn=978-1-904764-58-8 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=B5PjuAbEPooC&pg=PA108#v=twopage 208–209]}} ==Critical reception== As with the other films of the porno chic era, it was reviewed by the film critics of mainstream newspapers. The film's review in ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said, "With ''The Devil in Miss Jones'', the hard-core porno feature approaches an art form, one that critics may have a tough time ignoring in the future," and compared its plot to [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]'s play ''[[No Exit]]''.Lewis, p. 211 The review went on to say, "Damiano has expertly fashioned a bizarre melodrama," and described the opening scene as "a sequence so effective it would stand out in any legit theatrical feature". It finished by stating, "Booking a film of this technical quality into a standard sex house is tantamount to throwing it on the trash heap of most current hard-core fare." According to Peter Michelson there is, "a relatively small corpus of [pornographic] films—e.g., ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'', ''Devil in Miss Jones'', ''[[Behind the Green Door]]''—that have a minimal but still sufficient artistic interest to distinguish themselves from the rest of the genre".{{cite book|title=Speaking the unspeakable: a poetics of obscenity|publisher=SUNY Press|author=Michelson, Peter |year=1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X-jT4oEJ01QC&dq=%22Behind+the+Green+Door%22|isbn=0-7914-1223-7|page=235}} Other critics have described it as, along with ''Deep Throat'', one of the "two best erotic motion pictures ever made".{{cite book|title=Offensive literature: decensorship in Britain, 1960-1982|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|author=Sutherland, John |year=1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udkN4xWi2r0C|isbn=0-389-20354-8|page=136}} [[Roger Ebert]] gave ''Deep Throat'' a no-stars rating,{{cite web |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/deep-throat-1973 |title=Deep Throat |publisher=Rogerebert.com |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |date=March 6, 1973 |accessdate=April 7, 2015}} but described ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' as the "best" of the genre he had seen and gave it three stars out of a possible four. He wrote that the relatively high production values and storytelling were partly the reason for his positive review, but that Spelvin's performance was the main draw: "she is not only the best, but possibly the only, actress in the hard-core field. By that I mean when she's on the screen, her body and actions aren't the only reasons we're watching her. Alone among porno stars, she never seems exploited."{{cite web |last=Ebert |first=Roger |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=The Devil In Miss Jones - Film Review |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-devil-in-miss-jones-1973 |date=June 13, 1973 |work=[[RogerEbert.com]] |accessdate=February 7, 2015 }} [[William Friedkin]] has called it a "great film", partly because it was one of the few porn films with a proper storyline.{{cite book|title=The erotic thriller in contemporary cinema|publisher=Indiana University Press|author=Williams, Linda Ruth |year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QOiY931rxDEC|isbn=0-253-34713-0|page=134}} It was one of the first films to be inducted into the [[XRCO Hall of Fame]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dirtybob.com/xrco/hall.htm |title=HALL OF FAME |publisher=Dirty Bob/X-Rated Critics Organization |accessdate=June 15, 2015}} ==Soundtrack== The theme for the film was "I'm Comin' Home", sung by [[Linda November]].{{Discogs master |522918|name=The Devil In Miss Jones (Original Soundtrack Recording)|type=album }} Dialogue was heavily sampled on a track called "The Teacher" by electronic outfit Wave Mechanics in 1991 on the Oh'Zone label - the label who first released the acid house classic "[[Chime (song)|Chime]]" by British electronic music pioneers [[Orbital (band)|Orbital]] before it became a crossover hit in the UK. ==Sequels and remakes== In 2006, [[VCX]] employed [[Media Blasters]] to digitally re-master the film from the original 35mm film into a "Definitive Collectors Edition" 2-Disc set on DVD. This latest revision has been repackaged and supposedly has the best picture and audio quality of any original Devil In Miss Jones release. The DVDs contain the remastered feature, audio commentary with director [[Gerard Damiano]], a lengthy in-depth interview with Georgina Spelvin, the original trailer, the [[cable TV]] version, and a photo gallery. ===''The Devil in Miss Jones 2''=== (1982, [[VCA Pictures]]) Starring: [[Jacqueline Lorains|Jacqueline Lorians]], [[Georgina Spelvin]], [[Jack Wrangler]], [[Samantha Fox (actress)|Samantha Fox]], Anna Ventura, Joanna Storm, [[R. Bolla]], [[Sharon Mitchell]], [[Ron Jeremy]] written by Ellie Hayward and Henri Pachard; directed by [[Henri Pachard]]. A satirical take-off on the original, its title track was sung by [[Johnny Hartman]].{{cite journal|title=Jet|volume=63|number= 4|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|author=|date=4 Oct 1982|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEEDAAAAMBAJ|issn=0021-5996|page=55}} ===''The Devil in Miss Jones 3: A New Beginning''=== (1986, VCA Pictures) Starring [[Lois Ayres]], [[John Bailey (American actor)|Jack Baker]], [[Careena Collins]], [[Vanessa del Rio]], [[Amber Lynn]], Kari Foxx, [[Tom Byron]], Jennifer Noxt, Chanel, Keli Richards, [[Peter North (actor)|Peter North]], [[Mark Wallice]], and [[Paul Thomas (director)|Paul Thomas]]. [[Kevin James (pornographic actor)|Kevin James]] had a non-performing role. Written by Gregory Dark and Johnny Jump-Up and produced and directed by [[Gregory Dark]]. It won Best Film at the 1987 [[AVN Award]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.avnawards.com/index.php?content=pastwinners |title=AVN Awards Show |work=avnawards.com |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001081218/http://www.avnawards.com/index.php?content=pastwinners |archivedate=October 1, 2009 }} ===''The Devil in Miss Jones 4: The Final Outrage''=== (1986, VCA Pictures) Starring: Lois Ayres, [[Jack Baker (actor)|Jack Baker]], Patti Petite, Kristara Barrington, Keli Richards, [[Krista Lane]], Tamara Longley, [[Erica Boyer]], Paul Thomas, Ron Jeremy, F.M. Bradley and [[Kevin James (pornographic actor)|Kevin James]]. Written by Gregory Dark and Johnny Jump-Up; produced and directed by Gregory Dark. Parts 3 & 4 together won 'Best Classic [[DVD]]' at the 2000 AVN Awards. ===''The Devil in Miss Jones 5: The Inferno''=== (1995, VCA Pictures) Starring [[Juli Ashton]], Amanda Addams, Rip Hymen, Tammi Ann, Kelly O'Dell, Nicole Lace, Vanessa Chase, Ariana, Rowan Fairmont, Barbara Doll, [[Rebecca Lord]], [[Serenity (actress)|Serenity]], Sindee Coxx, Tom Byron, Dave Cummings, [[Mark Davis (pornographic actor)|Mark Davis]] written by Selwyn Harris; produced and directed by Gregory Dark. ===''The Devil in Miss Jones 6''=== (1999, VCA Pictures) Starring [[Stacy Valentine]], Vicca, Nikita, [[Randy Spears]], [[Juli Ashton]], Dizzy, Tina Tyler, [[Lacey Ogden]], Peris Bleu, Anita Cannibal, Scotty Schwartz written and directed by Antonio Passolini It won 'Top Renting Release of the Year' at the 2000 AVN Awards. ===''The New Devil in Miss Jones''=== (2005, [[Vivid Entertainment]]) Starring: [[Savanna Samson]], [[Jenna Jameson]], Rachel Rotten,{{cite interview|subject=Rachel Rotten|interviewer=Frank Meyer|title=The AVN Online Interview: Rachel Rotten|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/The-AVN-Online-Interview-Rachel-Rotten-38381.html |work=AVN|date=May 1, 2004|accessdate=February 4, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010225757/http://business.avn.com/articles/The-AVN-Online-Interview-Rachel-Rotten-38381.html|dead-url=yes|archivedate=2012-10-10}} Roxanne Hall, Angelica Sin, [[Vicky Vette]], [[Dick Smothers, Jr.]], [[Nick Manning]], [[Tony Tedeschi]], [[Georgina Spelvin]]; written by Dean Nash and Raven Touchstone; directed by [[Paul Thomas (pornographic actor)|Paul Thomas]]Spelvin, p. 271 and edited by [[Sonny Malone]]. At the 2006 [[AVN Awards]], the remake dominated the film categories, winning Best Art Direction, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Screenplay, Best Director, Best Actress, Best Film, Best Supporting Actress and Best All-Girl Sex Scene. The film cost $250,000 to produce, which, according to ''[[The New York Times]]'' film reviewer Mireya Navarro was "Vivid's most expensive (production) yet"[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/movies/MoviesFeatures/07nava.html Navarro, Mireya, "The Devil is still In", ''New York Times Film Review'', August 7, 2005] and one of the most expensive pornographic productions of all time. Georgina Spelvin, the star of the original film, then nearly 70 years old,{{cite web|url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story9333.phtml|title=New Devil in Miss Jones out Sept 21|work=ainews.com|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} took a non-sexual role as a cleaning woman and mentor to the new Miss Jones. ===''The Devil in Miss Jones: The Resurrection''=== (2010, [[Vivid Entertainment]]) Starring: [[Belladonna (actress)|Belladonna]], Savanna Samson, [[Penny Flame]], Carmella Bing, [[Rebeca Linares]], Victoria Sin, [[Kurt Lockwood]], Nick Manning, [[Steven St. Croix]], [[Evan Stone]], [[Tom Byron]]; written by Raven Touchstone and Tony G.; directed by Paul Thomas While it received several AVN award nominations, it didn't win any awards.. ===''The Devil in Miss Jones II: The Devil's Agenda''=== (1991, Arrow Productions) Starring: [[Alexandra Quinn]], [[Taylor Wane]], Cameo, [[Ron Jeremy]], [[Randy West (pornographic actor)|Randy West]], Cal Jammer, Biff Malibu, [[Jerry Butler (pornographic actor)|Jerry Butler]]; directed by [[Steve Drake]] While not considered part of the ''Devil in Miss Jones'' series by some, this movie nevertheless is a sequel in which Quinn plays Amanda Jones, who, in limbo after death, must choose between the devil (Jeremy) and an angel (West). Subsequent to this production, Arrow and VCX were involved in a copyright dispute over the original ''Devil in Miss Jones'' along with two other [[Golden Age of Porn]] films, ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'' and ''[[Debbie Does Dallas]]''.[http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/Arrow-V-C-X-Settle-Deep-Throat-Debbie-Does-Dallas-Case-451843.html Arrow, V.C.X. Settle 'Deep Throat'/'Debbie Does Dallas' Case], Mark Kernes, ''Adult Video News'', October 21, 2011 Both companies continue to sell ''Devil in Miss Jones''.[http://www.xxxdeepthroat.com/index.php?l=product_detail&p=9 1973 Original Edition DVD]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} product page at Arrow ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1973]] * [[Unsimulated sex in film|List of mainstream movies with unsimulated sex]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|30em}} '''Bibliography''' * {{cite book|title=Hollywood V. '''Wassan''' ({{lang-sd|{{Nastaliq وساڻ}} <small>([[Perso-Arabic script|Perso-Arabic]])</small>, वस्सान <small>([[Devanagari]])</small>}}) is a [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]] Rajput|Rajput]] tribe found in [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]]. After the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] in 1947, [[Hindu]] Wassans emigrated to [[India]].
== Distribution == Wassan is a surname of the cast from [[Ramgharia]] The Wassan are found mainly in the [[Sanghar District]] and [[Khairpur District]] of [[Sindh]]. Haji Nawab Khan Wassan and Pir Gudo in Kotdiji Taluka in [[Khairpur District]] are important villages of the tribe. Khan Bahadur Wassan of Kandiari and Khan Muhammad Wassan and his elder brother Haji Muhammad Saleh Wassan known as famus horse rider in Sanghar District as well as in Sindh Provence He also breeds many horse species in his form house known as village Haji Muhammad Mureed Wassan near kandiari District Sanghar. District Sanghar have remained prominent people of Wassan community.
Wassan community is politically supports two political parties: [[Pakistan Muslim League (F)]] and [[Pakistan Peoples Party]]. The supporters of both enjoy good relationship to one another on the basis of being members of same community. A sizeable number of the members of Wassan community are known as the followers of [[Sufi]] [[Pir Pagara]] (a spiritual Leader) and a prominent political figure of [[Pakistan]]. The name of Muhammad Khan Wassan is famous in Wassan family and as well as in agriculturist. He introduce new variety of cotton in Sindh. Muhammad Khan Wassan cultivated the between cotton his farm Abbas Farms in [[Shahdadpur]] and took bumper production of [[cotton]] and then he launched it to other areas of Sindh.
Wassans are widespread throughout [[Pakistan]], [[India]] and [[Saudi Arabia]]. There are many prominent poets, Directors and writers in this caste, like Hassan Wassan he is the First Program Director, Producer, Host, reporter & Model in various TV Channals Since 1996 & Wafa Hakim Wassan, whose famous two books are available in market: Ujra Gorha Mera Gal (Sindhi) and Chund Nainan Main (Sindhi).
According to traditions, Wassan are mainly [[Arab people|Arabs]] came from [[Saudi Arabia]] during the rule of [[Umayyad Caliphate]]. The Wassan are found mainly in the Sanghar District and Khairpur District of Sindh. Haji Nawab Khan Wassan and Pir Gudo in Kotdiji Taluka in Khairpur District are important villages of the tribe. Khan Bahadur Wassan of Kandiari and Khan Muhammad Wassan of Sanghar have remained prominent people of Wassan community. Whereas Manzoor Wassan is current Minister for Works and Services.
Wassan community is politically supports two political parties: Pakistan Muslim League (F) and Pakistan Peoples Party. The supporters of both enjoy good relationship to one another on the basis of being members of same community. A sizeable number of the members of Wassan community are known as the followers of Sufi Pir Pagara (a spiritual Leader) and a prominent political figure of Pakistan. The name of Muhammad Khan Wassan is famous in Wassan family and as well as in agriculturist. He introduce new variety of cotton in Sindh. Muhammad Khan Wassan cultivated the between cotton his farm Abbas Farms in Shahdadpur and took bumper production of cotton and then he launched it to other areas of Sindh.
Wassans are widespread throughout Pakistan, India and Saudi Arabia. It is one of the traditions of wassans not to get married their women to other castes same like sindhi sayyeds and Khuwajas.but nowadays this tradition is finished coz awareness came in people that it is wrong tradition . There are many prominent poets and writers in this caste, like Hassan Wassan he is the First Program Director, Host in verious TV Channals and Wafa Hakim Wassan, whose famous two books are available in market: Ujra Gorha Mera Gal (Sindhi) and Chund Nainan Main.

{{Infobox women by region | image = Khevsurian girl.jpg | caption = A Georgian woman wearing a national costume | gii = <!-- Gender Inequality Index, value and year, e.g. "0.610 (2012)" --> | gii_rank = <!-- Gender Inequality Index, rank --> | matdeath = <!-- Maternal mortality rate, per 100,000 --> | womparl = <!-- Women in national parliament, percent --> | femed = <!-- Females over 25 with secondary education, percent --> | womlab = <!-- Women in labour force, percent --> | ggg = 0.6750 (2013) | ggg_rank = 86th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12-13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}}
'''Women in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]''' live in a society which has been changing over the centuries, where, after decades of Soviet regime, from the 1990s onwards, the culture has seen rapid social changes and new emerging values, but has also been affected by economic instability.
==Historical context== {{Expand section|date=November 2017}} [[File:Mariam Jambakur-Orbeliani, prominent educator of Georgia (E. Europe).jpg|thumb|right|[[Mariam Jambakur-Orbeliani]], 19th century Georgian [[philanthropist]] and [[feminist]]]] For much of the 20th century, Georgia was part of the USSR. In 1991, after the Soviet dissolution, Georgia became an independent country. As with other countries of the former communist block, the transition from a planned economy to a market economy was hard, and unemployment, economic destabilization, and conflicts have harmed the population, especially in the 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gfsis.org/media/download/library/articles/papava/Papava_Reforming_of_the_Post-Soviet_Georgia_Economy_in_1991-2011.pdf |format=PDF |title=Georgian Foundation for Strategic and International Studies |website=Gfsis.org |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> In terms of population, more than 8 out of 10 inhabitants are ethnic Georgians, but there are also minorities such as Azeri, Armenians, Russians, and others. The vast majority of the population is [[Orthodox Christian]], but about one in ten are [[Muslim]]. The urbanization of the country is 53.6% (est. 2015). The [[total fertility rate]] (TFR) of 1.76 children born/woman (est. 2015) is below the replacement rate. The [[maternal mortality rate]] is 36 deaths/100,000 live births (est. 2015). <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/gg.html|title=The World Factbook|work=cia.gov|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>
==Constitutional provisions== The [[Constitution of Georgia (country)|Constitution of Georgia]] states at Article 14 that:"''Everyone is free by birth and is equal before law regardless of race, colour, language, religion, political and other opinions, national, ethnic and social belonging, origin, property and title, place of residence''."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.ge/files/68_1944_951190_CONSTIT_27_12.06.pdf |format=PDF |title=THE CONSTITUTION OF GEORGIA |website=Parliament.ge |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref>
== Social role of women == {{Expand section|date=November 2017}} [[File:Kartlis deda.JPG|thumb|right|[[Kartlis Deda]] monument]] Because [[Georgian culture]] is a patriarchal one, women are accorded a [[chivalric]] form of respect.<ref name=EC/> Women can have the role of both as "breadwinner and housewife". Most of the chores at home are done by women. There is no "explicit division of labor" according to gender, except in so-called "areas of physical labor" (an example is in the field of mining). The statue of [[Mother of Georgia]] (''Kartlis Deda'', or "Mother of [[Kartli]]") that stands at a monument in the hills above [[Tbilisi]] perhaps best symbolizes such national character: in her left hand she holds a bowl of wine with which she greets her friends and in her right is a sword drawn against her enemies. One of the most important and powerful rulers of Georgia was [[Tamar of Georgia|Queen (king of kings) Tamar the Great]]. In more recent history Georgian women have been able to acquire various positions in the [[Georgian Armed Forces|military]] including being among the few professional fighter and helicopter pilots of the country's small airforce and also a small number in the army's special forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/node/66663|title=Georgia: Women Soldiers Fight for the Right to Fight Like Men|first=Molly|last=Corso|date=8 March 2013|publisher=|accessdate=17 June 2016|via=EurasiaNet}}</ref> Many women also serve in the field of law enforcement and the [[Cabinet of Georgia|government]]. However, no women are allowed to become [[Orthodox church]] priests, or even to become Muslim [[mullah]]s.<ref name=EC>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/Ge-It/Georgia.html#b#ixzz2VlOqZAkg|title=Culture of Georgia - history, people, traditions, women, beliefs, food, customs, family, social|work=everyculture.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> The so-called "traditional stereotypes of gender-defined social roles" are undergoing changes because of the education being received by new generation of women.<ref name=EC/> Clothing norms stipulate that inside churches, head covering and dress or skirt for women are usually required.
==Employment== The Labour Code of Georgia has certain protections for women. Article 2 ''Labor Relations'' para. 3 prohibits discrimination based on "race, color, language, ethnic or social origin, nationality, origin, property, birth, place of residence, age, '''gender''', sexual orientation, disability, membership of a religious , social, political or other associations, including the trade unions, by marital status, political or other opinion".<ref name="matsne.gov.ge">{{cite web|url=https://matsne.gov.ge/ru/document/view/1155567 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 10, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420192014/https://matsne.gov.ge/ru/document/view/1155567 |archivedate=April 20, 2016 }}</ref> Art. 27 grants [[maternity leave]], <ref name="matsne.gov.ge"/> and Art 36 and Art 37 in general (and explicitly at sections Art 36(2)g together with Art 37(3)c) protect women from dismissal due to maternity, childbirth and child care, leave for a newborn child adoption and additional leave for child care.<ref name="matsne.gov.ge"/> The ''Law of Georgia on Gender Equality'' provides additional protections.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/91624 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 10, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420202134/https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/91624 |archivedate=April 20, 2016 }}</ref>
==Violence against women== In 2006, Georgia enacted ''Law of Georgia on Elimination of Domestic Violence, Protection and Support of Victims of Domestic Violence''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/26422?publication%3D4 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 11, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421175938/https://matsne.gov.ge/en/document/view/26422?publication=4 |archivedate=April 21, 2016 }}</ref> Georgia also ratified the [[Council of Europe Convention on Action against Trafficking in Human Beings]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/treaty/197/signatures|title=Full list|work=coe.int|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox women |image = File:Kuwait women's football team 2012.jpg | image_size = 350px |caption = Kuwaiti women. |gii = 0.274 (2012) |gii_rank = 47th |matdeath = 14 (2010) |womparl = 12.7% (2017) |womlab = 59.4% (2018)<ref name="web">[http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2012.pdf Gender Gap Report 2012] Page 52</ref> | ggg = 0.679 (2017) | ggg_rank = 94th | ggg_ref =<ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Human Rights of Kuwait}} {{Women in society sidebar}} '''[[Women]] in [[Kuwait]]''' are among the most emancipated women in the [[Middle East]] region. In 2014 and 2015, Kuwait was ranked first among Arab countries in the [[Global Gender Gap Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://widgets.weforum.org/gender-gap-report-2014/#mena|title=The Global Gender Gap Index 2014 - World Economic Forum|publisher=World Economic Forum}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticlePrintPage.aspx?id=2405039&language=en|title=Kuwait highest in closing gender gap: WEF}}</ref><ref name="wef">{{cite web|url=http://reports.weforum.org/global-gender-gap-report-2015/the-global-gender-gap-index-results-in-2015/|title=Global Gender Gap Index Results in 2015|publisher=World Economic Forum}}</ref> In 2013, 53% of Kuwaiti women participated in the labor force.<ref name="gend">{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2013/cr13337.pdf|title=Kuwait: Selected Issues|page=17|quote=Kuwait has higher female labor market participation than other GCC countries; further improvements in labor force participation can support future growth prospects. Kuwait’s labor force participation rate for Kuwaiti women (53 percent) is slightly above the world average (51 percent) and much higher than the [[Middle East and North Africa|MENA]] average (21 percent).}}</ref> Kuwaiti women outnumber men in the workforce.<ref name=gnw/>
Women in Kuwait have experienced many changes since the discovery of oil. They have a long history of official political and social activism which started in the 1960s and continues today. In the 1950s their access to education and employment increased dramatically.
==Women in the pre-oil era== From the 17th century until the discovery of oil in the 1950s, the [[economy of Kuwait]] was largely dependent on maritime trade. While men were seafaring, Kuwait’s women managed their homes, and controlled family affairs and finances. For those families that could afford it, houses were built with a courtyard and a [[harem]] where women spent most of their time. This structure, along with high windows and doors that faced into the house rather than the street, removed women from public vision. Urban, upper-class women’s participation in the public sphere was limited.<ref>{{cite book|last=al-Mughni|first=Haya|title=Women in Kuwait: The Politics of Gender|year=2001|publisher=Saqi|location=London}}</ref> However, women from less fortunate circumstances had a much less secluded experience; they went to the [[suq]] on a daily basis, fetched drinking water and washed their families’ clothes on the beach.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sweet|first=Louise E.|title=Camel Raiding of North Arabian Bedouin: A Mechanism of Ecological Adaptation|year=1970|location=New York|pages=271}}</ref> Kuwaiti girls began learning scripture in 1916 when the first Quran school was established. After this many women of modest means began working as religious instructors. The first private school opened in 1926; it taught reading, writing, and [[embroidery]]. Public schooling began in 1937 though enrollment in it was low for some time; however, by the 1940s many young Kuwaiti women were enrolled in primary school. It was often women themselves who pushed for these educational advances and opportunities and in 1956 a group of young women burned their [[abaya|abayyas]] to protest their right to go abroad to study.
==Employment== The participation of Kuwaiti women in the labor force is much higher than the regional GCC average,<ref name=ilo/> Kuwait has the highest percentage of working female citizens in the GCC.<ref name=gnw/><ref name="ilo">{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/@arabstates/@ro-beirut/documents/meetingdocument/wcms_330314.pdf|title=The Kuwaiti Labour Market and Foreign Workers: Understanding the Past and Present to Provide a Way Forward|work=[[International Labour Organization]]|page=13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BfZR8SNg0bwC&pg=PA43&dq|title=Kuwait: Selected Issues and Statistical Appendix|work=[[International Monetary Fund]] |year=2012|pages=43}}</ref> Kuwaiti women outnumber men in the workforce.<ref name="gnw">{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwait-leads-gulf-states-in-women-in-workforce-1.1705940|title=Kuwait leads Gulf states in women in workforce|work=Gulf News|year=2016}}</ref>
In 2013, 53% of Kuwaiti women participated in the labor force.<ref name=gend/> Kuwait's labor force participation rate for Kuwaiti women is much higher than the [[Middle East and North Africa|MENA]] average.<ref name=gend/>
==Organizations and activism== Women’s activism in Kuwait began in the 1950s. The first women’s organization, the Arab Women’s Renaissance Association (later changed to the Family Renaissance Association), was established by Noureya Al-Saddani in 1962 and was soon followed by the Women’s Cultural and Social Society in February 1963. The Girls Club (Nadi Alfatat) was established in 1975, its initial focus was on women in sport. In 1981 Bayader As-Salam, a religious group whose objective was cultural awareness, was formed. The same year Sheikha Latifa Al-Sabah’s Islamic Care Association was established, it sought to spread Islam and an Islamic lifestyle and conduct.<ref>{{cite book|last=Al-Saddani|first=Noureya|title=The Arab Women’s Movement in the 20th Century 1917-1981|year=1982|location=Kuwait}}</ref>
Kuwaiti women played a large role in resisting the Iraqi invasion in 1990. They mobilized the opposition, started an underground resistance paper called “al-Kuwaitiya”, passed weapons and ammunition through Iraqi checkpoints, transported and planted explosives using abayas, collected and distributed food and medicine, and ran shelters for the sick and disabled. During the invasion they also organized a large demonstration in defiance of the invasion, which cost some of them their lives.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Maria|first=Julia|author2=Hadi Ridha |title=Women and War: The Role Kuwaiti Women Played During the Iraqi Occupation|journal=Journal of International Development|year=2001|volume=13|pages=583–598|doi=10.1002/jid.782}}</ref> Women became active in Islamist groups in the 1980s when Islamism was on the rise in Kuwait.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hirmats|first=Aiko|title=The Changing Nature of the Parliamentary System in Kuwait: Islamists, Tribes, and Women in Recent Elections|journal=Kyoto Bulletin of Islamic Area Studies|year=2011|volume=4|issue=1&2|pages=62–73|url=http://www.asafas.kyoto-u.ac.jp/kias/pdf/kb4_1and2/08hiramatsu.pdf}}</ref> Through their early activity in these groups, many women acquired organizational skills which they were able to utilize in the campaign for [[suffrage]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=al-Mughni|first=Haya|title=L’Émergence du Féminisme Islamique au Koweït|journal=Revue des Mondes Musulmans et de la Méditerranée|year=2010|volume=128|url=http://remmm.revues.org/6899|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref>
===Women in the arts=== Kuwait’s long tradition of artistic expression has been spearheaded and organized by women. Women’s involvement in the fine arts dates back to at least 1969 when Najat Sultan along with her brother Ghazi established the Sultan Gallery, which served as a propagator for contemporary and secular movements in Arab art. The gallery was shut after the Iraqi invasion and reopened in 2006 by Farida Sultan. It currently focuses on contemporary photography.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sultan Gallery|url=http://www.sultangallery.com/mission-statement/|accessdate=6 April 2014}}</ref> Sheikha Hussah Al Sabah established [[Dar al-Athar al-Islamiyyah]] in 1983, and Dar al-Funoon gallery for contemporary art in 1992.<ref>{{cite news|last=Al-Qassemi|first=Sultan Sooud|title=The Women Trailblazers of Gulf Arab Art|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sultan-sooud-alqassemi/the-women-trailblazers-of-gulf-arab-art_b_3012443.html|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=4 April 2013}}</ref>
Contemporary artists include: [[Thuraya Al-Baqsami|Thuraya al Baqsami]], who trained in [[Cairo]] and [[Moscow]] whose works can be found in museums worldwide;<ref>{{cite web|title=Kuwaiti print maker Thuraya Al-Baqsami on identity, Kuwaiti art scene, writing|url=http://artradarjournal.com/2008/11/28/kuwaiti-print-maker-thuraya-al-baqsami-on-identity-kuwait-art-scene-writing-art-interview/|publisher=Art Radar Asia|accessdate=6 April 2014}}</ref> [[Shurooq Amin]], whose subversive art pieces aim to challenge perceptions of society in the Gulf;<ref>{{cite news|last=Shurafa|first=Sara|title=Kuwaiti artist fights for freedom of expression|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwaiti-artist-fights-for-freedom-of-expression-1.1004397|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=[[Gulf News]]|date=4 April 2012}}</ref> [[Fatima Al Qadiri]] (member of [[Future Brown]]), an artist, musician and composer whose work is inspired by her experience in the [[Gulf War]];<ref>{{cite web|last=Read|first=Max|title=Trax Read: Listen to a Full Stream of Fatima Al Qadiri's Amazing Desert Strike EP|url=http://gawker.com/5953901/trax-read-listen-to-a-full-stream-of-fatima-al-qadiris-amazing-desert-strike-ep/all|publisher=[[Gawker]]|accessdate=6 April 2014| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819051257/http://gawker.com/5953901/trax-read-listen-to-a-full-stream-of-fatima-al-qadiris-amazing-desert-strike-ep/all | archivedate= August 19, 2016|deadurl=yes}}</ref> [[Monira Al Qadiri]], whose art explores gender and religious and cultural identities;<ref>{{cite web|last=Al Qadiri|first=Monira|title=About Mounira|url=http://www.moniraalqadiri.com/#!about/c10fk|accessdate=6 April 2014}}</ref> and [[Nada Al Shammari]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/nadaa|title=Nada F. Al-Shammari|website=Vimeo|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> award-winning documentary [https://vimeo.com/nadaa/trailblazingwomeninthehistoryofkuwait filmmaker], documenting the contribution of women to contemporary culture and society in the Gulf States with '[https://vimeo.com/nadaa/trailblazingwomeninthehistoryofkuwait Trailblazing Women in the History of Kuwait]' and '[https://vimeo.com/nadaa/tbwwomeninscienceandtechnology Trailblazing Women in Science and Technology]'.
==Political participation== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Kuwaiti girls campaigning in elections.jpg|thumb|left|Young Kuwaiti women campaigning in 2012 elections]] --> The women's [[suffrage]] campaign started in 1971 when a group led by Noureya Al-Saddani took a proposal to [[National Assembly (Kuwait)|parliament]] to grant women political rights. The proposal was rejected. In the early 1990s, women campaigned heavily for the vote; they held protests outside of election headquarters and between 2000 and 2005 a number of women filed court cases against the Minister of Interior for his refusal to include women in election tables.<ref>{{cite web|last=Haidar|first=Khalil Ali|title=Kuwaiti women's movement and the religious current|url=http://www.14october.com/news.aspx?newsno=3002274|publisher=14 October|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref> In 2004 women demonstrated inside the parliament hall for the vote, and a year later they held one of the largest demonstrations in Kuwait’s history.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shultziner|first=Doron|author2=Mary Ann Tétreault |title=Paradoxes of Democratic Progress in Kuwait: The Case of the Kuwaiti Women’s Rights Movement|journal=Muslim World Journal of Human Rights|year=2011|volume=7|issue=2|pages=1–25|doi=10.2202/1554-4419.1192}}</ref>
In 1999, the Emir [[Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah|Sheikh Jaber Al-Sabah]] promulgated a decree granting women [[suffrage]] after the parliament was dissolved, however, it was overturned by the new parliament just months later by two-votes difference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alwatan.kuwait.tt/articledetails.aspx?id=434133&yearquarter=20152|title=المرأة الكويتية تحتفل اليوم بالذكرى العاشرة لحصولها على حقوقها السياسية|author=|date=|website=الوطـــن الإلكترونية}}</ref> Kuwaiti women were granted the right to vote in May 2005.<ref>{{cite news|title=UN and US congratulate Kuwait over women’s right to vote|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/world/other-world/un-and-us-congratulate-kuwait-over-women-146-s-right-to-vote-1.288029|accessdate=2014-03-15|newspaper=Gulf News|date=May 18, 2005}}</ref> Women voted for the first time in June 2006, and in these elections 28 women ran out of a pool of 250 candidates though none won.<ref>{{cite news|title=Historic first time vote for Kuwaiti women|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/historic-first-time-vote-for-kuwaiti-women-1.183897|accessdate=2014-03-15|date=June 29, 2006}}</ref> Almost exactly four years after women were given full political rights, four were elected into parliament for the first time. The winners in the 2009 elections were: [[Massouma Al Mubarak]] (the first Kuwaiti woman appointed to the cabinet), [[Aseel Al Awadhi]], [[Rola Dashti]], and [[Salwa Al Jassar]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Kuwaiti women in first-ever win of four parliamentary seats|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/kuwaiti-women-in-first-ever-win-of-four-parliamentary-seats-1.2021|accessdate=2014-03-15|newspaper=Gulf News|date=May 17, 2009}}</ref> In 2011, Kuwait was ranked highest of all [[Arab states|Arab countries]] in [[gender equality]] in the [[Human Development Report]]'s [[Gender Inequality Index]].<ref name="eq">{{cite web|url=https://chronicle.fanack.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2014/10/gender-inequality_kuwait_gender_730px_03_c1f442976a.jpg|title=Gender inequality |publisher=fanack.com |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref>
==Notable Kuwaiti women== * [[Noureya Al-Saddani]]: An author, historian, broadcaster and director, Al-Saddani started the first women’s organization in Kuwait. In 1971 she proposed to the National Assembly to grant women's political rights. During the invasion she worked in charity and mobilized the [[diaspora]]; upon her return to Kuwait she put together radio biographies of all the female martyrs in the invasion.<ref>{{cite web|last=Basha|first=Sadoon|title=Noureya Al-Saddani|url=http://www.kuwait-history.net/vb/showthread.php?t=5496|publisher=History of Kuwait|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref> * [[Loulwa Abdulwahab Essa Al-Qatami]]: Al-Qatami the first woman to study abroad, she left Kuwait on 12/6/1955 for a degree in Education. Upon her return, she and a few other Kuwaiti women founded the Women's Cultural and Social Society in 1963. She and the group have been instrumentally active in advancements for women since the 1960s; they work on mobilizing women, raising awareness and philanthropy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lulwa Al-Qitami|url=http://www.1000peacewomen.org/eng/friedensfrauen_biographien_gefunden.php?WomenID=909|publisher=Peace Women Across the Globe}}</ref> * [[Sarah Akbar]]: Akbar is Kuwait’s first Petroleum Engineer in the field. During the invasion, Akbar led a group of oil employees to maintain machinery and electricity and after the Iraqi troops left and set several oil fields on fire, Akbar set up a team to control and extinguish the fires, earning her the nickname “firefighter”.<ref>{{cite web|last=Arabic Knowledge@Wharton|title=Sara Akbar Makes a Name for Herself in the Oil Industry|url=http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/sara-akbar-makes-a-name-for-herself-in-the-oil-industry/|publisher=University of Pennsylvania|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref> * [[Asrar Al-Qabandi]]: Al-Qabandi was a martyr of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. During the occupation she helped people flee to safety, smuggled weapons and money into Kuwait as well as disks from the Ministry of Civil Information to safety, cared for many wounded by the war, and destroyed monitoring devices used by the Iraqi troops. She was captured and subsequently killed by Iraqi troops in January 1991.<ref>{{cite web|title=The ‘Tomboy’ Who Took On Takrit|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/165411/reftab/96/Default.aspx|publisher=Arab Times|accessdate=2014-03-15}}</ref> * [[Laila al-Othman]] is one of Kuwait's most famous authors and columnists. She has written a number of short stories and novels and often deals with themes that challenge traditional norms. She has faced conservative resistance to her work.<ref>{{cite news|last=Abdallah|first=Mariam|title=Laila al-Othman: A Life of Difference and Defiance|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/2852|newspaper=Al-Akhbar|year=2011}}</ref>
==Non-national women== Kuwait has a very high percentage of expatriates. Many Egyptian, Palestinian, Filipino and Southeast Asian women live in Kuwait. Palestinian women have worked in Kuwait since the 1950s, historically as teachers in girls’ schools.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ghabra|first=Shafeeq|title=Palestinians in Kuwait|year=1987|publisher=Westview|location=Boulder}}</ref> Nearly 90% of Kuwaiti households employ a foreigner worker, most often a South Asian woman.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shah|first=Nasra M. |author2=Makhdoom A. Shah |author3=Rafiqul Islam Chowdhury |author4=Indu Menon|title=Foreign domestic workers in Kuwait: Who employs how many|journal=Asian and Pacific Migration Journal|year=2002|volume=11|issue=2|url=http://www.smc.org.ph/administrator/uploads/apmj_pdf/APMJ2002N2ART4.pdf}}</ref> These women's labor is crucial to the social reproduction of Kuwait, though they occupy a marginal status and are not granted state protection or oversight.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ahmed|first=Attiya|title=Explanation is Not the Point: Domestic Work, Islamic Dawa and Becoming Muslim in Kuwait|journal=The Asia Pacific Journal of Anthropology|year=2010|volume=11|issue=34}}</ref> Non-Nationals are subject to residence and labor laws, which prevent them from permanently settling in Kuwait.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Longva|first=Anh Nga|title=Kuwaiti Women at a Crossroads: Privileged Development and the Constraints of Ethnic Stratification|journal=International Journal of Middle East Studies|year=1993|volume=25|issue=3|pages=443–456|doi=10.1017/s0020743800058864}}</ref> Under the [[kafala system]], whereby all migrants must have a citizen who sponsors their residence in Kuwait, many [[Migrant workers in Kuwait|migrant workers]] cannot leave or enter the country without their employer’s permission and are often exploited.

The '''Yunnan Ethnic Village''' ({{zh|s=云南民族村|p=Yúnnán Mínzú Cūn}}) is a theme park that displays the various [[folklore]], culture, and [[architecture]] of 26 ethnic groups in [[Yunnan]] Province, China.<ref name=travel>https://www.travelchinaguide.com/attraction/yunnan/kunming/nationalities-village.htm{{full|date=September 2018}}</ref> The park's major goal is mainly to display some aspects of Yunnan's ethnicity, cultural diversity, and heritage.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.annals.2010.10.009 |title=Ethnic tourism and cultural representation |journal=Annals of Tourism Research |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=561–85 |year=2011 |last1=Yang |first1=Li }}</ref> Located in the southwest suburbs of [[Kunming]] next to [[Dianchi]] lake, Yunnan Ethnic Village covers an area of 89 [[hectares]] including 31 hectares of water.<ref name=travel/> It is classified as a AAAA-class tourist attraction.
==Ethnic groups represented== The following ethnic groups are represented in the Yunnan Ethnic Village: *Dai (傣族:pinyin: dǎi zú) *Bai (白族:pinyin: bái zú) *Yi (彝族:pinyin: yí zú) *Naxi (纳西族:pinyin: nà xī zú) *Wa (佤族:pinyin: wǎ zú) *Bulang (布朗族:pinyin: bùlǎng zú) *Jinuo (基诺族:pinyin: jīnuò zú) *Lahu (拉祜族:pinyin: lā hù zú) *Tibetan (藏族:pinyin: zàng zú) *Jingpo (景颇族:pinyin: jǐngpō zú) *Hani (哈尼族:pinyin: hāní zú) *De Ang (德昂族:pinyin: dé áng zú) *Zhuang (壮族:pinyin: zhuàng zú) *Hmong (苗族:pinyin: miáo zú) *Shui (水族:pinyin: Shuĭ zú) *Nu (怒族:pinyin: Nù zú) *Mongol (蒙古族:pinyin: měnggǔ zú) *Buyi (布依族:pinyin: bùyī zú) *Dulong (独龙族:pinyin: dúlóng zú) *Lisu (傈僳族:pinyin: lìsù zú) *Pumi (普米族:pinyin: pǔmǐ zú) *Manchu (满族:pinyin: mǎn zú) *Hui (回族:pinyin: huí zú) *Yao (瑶族:pinyin: yáo zú) *Achang (阿昌族:pinyin: āchāng zú)
==Special events== *Water-Splashing Festival (April 13-16) of Dai minority *Torch Festival (June 24 in the lunar calendar) of Yi minority<ref name=travel/> *New Rice Festival (新米节:pinyin: xīn mǐ jié) of Jinuo minority, from the end of July to the beginning of August
==Transport== 1310 Dianchi Road, [[Kunming]], [[Yunnan]]. It is served by buses No. 44, 73, and A1.<ref>http://www.visitourchina.com/kunming/attraction/yunnan-ethnic-village.html{{full|date=September 2018}}</ref>
